owl:Ontology.rdfs:comment: This ontology contains terms and definitions based on the 2016 SKOS-RDF version of the IUGS Commission for Geoscience Information (CGI) Geoscience Terminology Working Group Event Environment vocabulary to describe the physical setting within which a GeologicEvent takes place. GeologicEnvironment is construed broadly to include physical settings on the Earth surface specified by climate, tectonics, physiography or geography, and settings in the Earthâ€™s interior specified by pressure, temperature, chemical environment, or tectonics. Environments are places. Designed for use in the eventEnvironment property in GeoSciML GeologicEvent features.
dct:creator-- CGI Geoscience Terminology Working Group
owl:Ontology.rdfs:label: Setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A drainage channel along which runoff no longer occurs, as on an alluvial fan
owl:Class.rdfs:label: abandoned river channel setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Marine environment in which carbonate sediment does not dissolve before reaching the sea floor and can accumulate.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: above carbonate compensation depth setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The ocean environment at water depths between 3500 and 6000 metres
owl:Class.rdfs:label: abyssal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Plate margin setting on continental crust.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: active continental margin setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Divergent plate margin at which new oceanic crust is being formed
owl:Class.rdfs:label: active spreading center setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sedimentary setting in which wind is the dominant process producing, transporting, and depositing sediment. Typically has low-relief plain or piedmont slope physiography.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: aeolian process setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Modern algal flats are found on rock or mud in areas flooded only by the highest tides and are often subject to high evaporation rates. Algal flats survive only when an area is salty enough to eliminate snails and other herbivorous animals that eat algae, yet is not so salty that the algae cannot survive. The most common species of algae found on algal flats are blue-green algae of the genera Scytonema and Schizothrix. These algae can tolerate the daily extremes in temperature and oxygen that typify conditions on the flats. Other plants sometimes found on algal flats include one-celled green algae, flagellates, diatoms, bacteria, and isolated scrubby red and black mangroves, as well as patches of saltwort. Animals include false cerith, cerion snails, fiddler crabs, and great land crabs. Flats with well developed algal mats are restricted for the most part to the Keys, with Sugarloaf and Crane Keys offering prime examples of algal flat habitat. (Audubon, 1991)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: algal flat setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A low, outspread, relatively flat to gently sloping mass of loose rock material, shaped like an open fan or a segment of a cone, deposited by a stream (esp. in a semiarid region) at the place where it issues from a narrow mountain valley upon a plain or broad valley, or where a tributary stream is near or at its junction with the main stream, or wherever a constriction in a valley abruptly ceases or the gradient of the stream suddenly decreases, it is steepest near the mouth of the valley where its apex points upstream, and it slopes gently and convexly outward with gradually decreasing gradient
owl:Class.rdfs:label: alluvial fan setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/,
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An assemblage landforms produced by alluvial and fluvial processes (braided streams, terraces, etc.) that form low gradient, regional ramps along the flanks of mountains and extend great distances from their sources (e.g.high Plains of North America). (NRCS GLOSSARY OF LANDFORM AND GEOLOGIC TERMS). A level or gently sloping tract or a slightly undulating land surface produced by extensive deposition of alluvium... Synonym-- wash plain,...river plain, aggraded valley plain,... (Jackson, 1997, p. 17). May include one or more River plain systems.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: alluvial plain setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting depleted in oxygen, typically subaqueous.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: anoxic setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/,
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting characterized by mean annual precipitation of 10 inches (25 cm) or less. (Jackson, 1997, p. 172). Equivalent to SLTT 'Desert setting', but use 'Arid' to emphasize climatic nature of setting definition.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: arid or semi arid environment setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Tectonic setting adjacent to a volcanic arc formed above a subduction zone. The back arc setting is on the opposite side of the volcanic arc from the trench at which oceanic crust is consumed in a subduction zone. Back arc setting includes terrane that is affected by plate margin and arc-related processes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: back arc setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The landward side of a reef. The term is often used adjectivally to refer to deposits within the restricted lagoon behind a barrier reef, such as the back-reef facies of lagoonal deposits. In some places, as on a platform-edge reef tract, back reef refers to the side of the reef away from the open sea, even though no land may be nearby
owl:Class.rdfs:label: backreef setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A narrow, elongate sand or gravel ridge rising slightly above the high-tide level and extending generally parallel with the shore, but separated from it by a lagoon (Shepard, 1954, p.1904), estuary, or marsh, it is extended by longshore transport and is rarely more than several kilometers long.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: barrier beach setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: setting meant to include all the various geographic elements typically associated with a barrier island coastline, including the barrier islands, and geomorphic/geographic elements that are linked by processes associated with the presence of the island (e.g. wash over fans, inlet channel, back barrier lagoon).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: barrier island coastline setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A lagoon that is roughly parallel to the coast and is separated from the open ocean by a strip of land or by a barrier reef. Tidal influence is typically restricted and the lagoon is commonly hypersaline.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: barrier lagoon setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An ombrotrophic or ombrogene peat/bog whose nutrient supply is exclusively from rain water (including snow and atmospheric fallout) therefore making nutrients extremely oligotrophic
owl:Class.rdfs:label: basin bog setting

owl:Class.terms:source: Bates & Jackson, 1987, Heezen & Laughton, 1963, Reading, 1978, p. 390
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Near flat areas of ocean floor, slope less than 1:1000, generally receive only distal turbidite and pelagic sediments.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: basin plain setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The ocean environment at water depths between 200 and 3500 metres
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bathyal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The unconsolidated material at the shoreline that covers a gently sloping zone, typically with a concave profile, extending landward from the low-water line to the place where there is a definite change in material or physiographic form (such as a cliff), or to the line of permanent vegetation (usually the effective limit of the highest storm waves), at the shore of a body of water, formed and washed by waves or tides, usually covered by sand or gravel, and lacking a bare rocky surface.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: beach setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Marine environment in which water is deep enough that carbonate sediment goes into solution before it can accumulate on the sea floor.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: below carbonate compensation depth setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A ridgelike or moundlike structure, layered or massive, built by sedentary calcareous organisms, esp. corals, and consisting mostly of their remains, it is wave-resistant and stands topographically above the surrounding contemporaneously deposited sediment.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: biological reef setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Topogeneous bog/peat whose moisture content is largely dependent on surface water. It is relatively rich in plant nutrients, nitrogen, and mineral matter, is mildly acidic to nearly neutral, and contains little or no cellulose, forms in topographic depressions with essential stagnat or non-moving minerotrophic water supply
owl:Class.rdfs:label: blanket bog

owl:Class.terms:source: Jackson, 1997, North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/,
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Waterlogged, spongy ground, consisting primarily of mosses, containing acidic, decaying vegetation that may develop into peat.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bog setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A stream that divides into or follows an interlacing or tangled network of several small branching and reuniting shallow channels separated from each other by ephemeral branch islands or channel bars, resembling in plan the strands of a complex braid. Such a stream is generally believed to indicate an inability to carry all of its load, such as an overloaded and aggrading stream flowing in a wide channel on a floodplain
owl:Class.rdfs:label: braided river channel setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A shoreline setting in which terrigenous input is minor compared to local carbonate sediment production. Constructional biogenic activity is an important element in geomorphic development.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: carbonate dominated shoreline setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A natural underground open space, it generally has a connection to the surface, is large enough for a person to enter, and extends into darkness. The most common type of cave is formed in limestone by dissolution.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cave setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A dune field on low-lying land recently abandoned or built up by the sea, the dunes may ascend a cliff and travel inland.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: coastal dune field setting

owl:Class.terms:source: based on Neuendorf et al, 2005, p. 125
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A low relief plain bordering a water body extending inland to the nearest elevated land, sloping very gently towards the water body. Distinguished from alluvial plain by presence of relict shoreline-related deposits or morphology.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: coastal plain setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Tectonic setting in which two continental crustal plates impact and are sutured together after intervening oceanic crust is entirely consumed at a subduction zone separating the plates. Such collision typically involves major mountain forming events, exemplified by the modern Alpine and Himalayan mountain chains.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: collisional setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Metamorphism of country rock at the contact of an igneous body. Because metamorphism inherently requires elevated temperature or pressure, it is necessarily an Earth interior setting
owl:Class.rdfs:label: contact metamorphic setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An area of the continental margin between the shoreline and the continental slope that is topographically more complex than the continental shelf. It is characterized by ridges and basins, some of which are below the depth of the continental shelf. An example is the southern California continental borderland,.... (Jackson, 1997, p. 138)..
owl:Class.rdfs:label: continental borderland setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: That type of the Earth's crust which underlies the continents and the continental shelves, it is equivalent to the sial and continental sima and ranges in thickness from about 25 km to more than 70 km under mountain ranges, averaging ~40 km. The density of the continental crust averages ~2.8 g/cm3 and is ~2.7 g.cm3 in the upper layer. The velocities of compressional seismic waves through it average ~6.5 km/s and are less than ~7.0 km/sec.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: continental crustal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Extended terrane in a zone of continental breakup, may include incipient oceanic crust. Examples include Red Sea, East Africa Rift, Salton Trough
owl:Class.rdfs:label: continental rift setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: That part of the ocean floor that is between the shoreline and the continental slope (or, when there is no noticeable continental slope, a depth of 200 m). It is characterized by its gentle slope of 0.1 degree (Jackson, 1997, p. 138). Continental shelves have a classic shoreline-shelf-slope profile termed 'clinoform'.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: continental shelf setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The outermost layer or shell of the Earth, defined according to various criteria, including seismic velocity, density and composition, that part of the Earth above the Mohorovicic discontinuity, made up of the sial and the sima.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: crustal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The abandoned, bow- or horseshoe-shaped channel of a former meander, left when the stream formed a cutoff across a narrow meander neck. Note that these are typically lakes, thus also lacustrine.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cutoff meander setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Deep ocean basin with steep (average 10 degrees) slope toward land, more gentle slope (average 5 degrees) towards the sea, and abundant seismic activity on landward side of trench. Does not denote water depth, but may be very deep.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: deep sea trench setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A narrow zone where deposition in deltas is most active, consisting of a continuous sheet of sand, and occurring within the effective depth of wave erosion (10 m or less). It is the zone separating the prodelta from the delta plain, and it may or may not be steep\
owl:Class.rdfs:label: delta front setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The level or nearly level surface composing the landward part of a large or compound delta, strictly, an alluvial plain characterized by repeated channel bifurcation and divergence, multiple distributary channels, and interdistributary flood basins
owl:Class.rdfs:label: delta plain setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Environments at the mouth of a river or stream that enters a standing body of water (ocean or lake). The delta forms a triangular or fan-shaped plain of considerable area. Subaerial parts of the delta are crossed by many distributaries of the main river, and commonly extend beyond the general trend of the coast. Subaqueous parts of the delta merge with the adjacent basin floor, and are progressively influenced by non-fluvial processes. Deltas result from the accumulation of sediment supplied by the river in such quantities that it is not removed by tides, waves, and currents. Adapted from the Glossary of Geology definition for delta (Jackson, 1997, p. 167).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: deltaic system setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A divergent stream flowing away from the main stream and not returning to it, as in a delta or on an alluvial plain
owl:Class.rdfs:label: delta distributary channel setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The mouth of a delta distributary channel where fluvial discharge moves from confined to unconfined flow conditions
owl:Class.rdfs:label: delta distributary mouth setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Extensive deposits on sand in an area where the supply is abundant. As a characteristic, individual dunes somewhat resemble barchans but are highly irregular in shape and crowded, erg areas of the Sahara are an example.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: dunefield setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Contained, embedded, or carried within the body of a glacier or ice sheet, said of meltwater streams, till, drift, moraine
owl:Class.rdfs:label: englacial setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Marine setting situated within the interior of the continent, rather than at the edge of a continent.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: epicontinental marine setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A delta that has filled, or is in the process of filling, an estuary
owl:Class.rdfs:label: estuarine delta setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A lagoon produced by the temporary sealing of a river estuary by a storm barrier. Such lagoons are usually seasonal and exist until the river breaches the barrier, they occur in regions of low or spasmodic rainfall
owl:Class.rdfs:label: estuarine lagoon setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Environments at the seaward end or the widened funnel-shaped tidal mouth of a river valley where fresh water comes into contact with seawater and where tidal effects are evident (adapted from Glossary of Geology, Jackson, 1997, p. 217).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: estuary setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Tectonic setting characterized by extension of the upper crust manifested by formation of rift valleys or basin and range physiography, with arrays of low to high angle normal faults. Modern examples include the North Sea, East Africa, and the Basin and Range of the North American Cordillera. Typically applied in continental crustal settings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: extended terrane setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Material originated outside of the Earth or its atmosphere.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: extra terrestrial setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Spreading center at which the opening rate is greater than 100 mm per year.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fast spreading center setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The surface or strip of relatively smooth land adjacent to a river channel, constructed by the present river in its existing regimen and covered with water when the river overflows its banks. It is built of alluvium carried by the river during floods and deposited in the sluggish water beyond the influence of the swiftest current. A river has one floodplain and may have one or more terraces representing abandoned floodplains
owl:Class.rdfs:label: floodplain setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Tectonic setting between a subduction-related trench and a volcanic arc
owl:Class.rdfs:label: forearc setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The exterior area of an orogenic belt where deformation occurs without significant metamorphism. Generally the foreland is closer to the continental interior than other portions of the orogenic belt are.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: foreland setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The seaward side of a reef, the slope covered with deposits of coarse reef talus
owl:Class.rdfs:label: forereef setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A desert plain strewn with wind-abraded pebbles, or gibbers, a gravelly desert.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: gibber plain setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Areas adjacent to glacial front dominated by sediment and water supplied by glacial melting.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: glacial outwash plain setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Settings adjacent to edges of confined glacier.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: glacier lateral setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Earth surface setting with geography defined by spatial relationship to glaciers (e.g. on top of a glacier, next to a glacier, in front of a glacier...). Processes related to moving ice dominate sediment transport and deposition and landform development. Includes subaqueous, shoreline, and terrestrial settings that are impacted by the presence of glaciers. Considered a geographically defined setting in that a glacier is a geographic feature.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: glacier related setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Region of sediment deposition due to melting of glacier ice. ablation and flow till setting.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: glacier terminus setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The deepest oceanic environment, i.e., over 6000 m in depth. Always in deep sea trench.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hadal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: High pressure environment characterized by geothermal gradient significantly lower than standard continental geotherm, enviornment in which blueschist facies metamorphic rocks form. Typically associated with subduction zones.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: high pressure low temperature earth interior setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/, Hawley, J.W., and Parsons, R.B. 1980. Glossary of selected geomorphic and geologic terms. Mimeo. USDA Soil Conservation Service, West National Technical Center, Portland, OR. 30 p.
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Earth surface setting characterized by surface slope angles high enough that gravity alone becomes a significant factor in geomorphic development, as well as base-of-slope areas influenced by hillslope processes. Hillslope activities include creep, sliding, slumping, falling, and other downslope movements caused by slope collapse induced by gravitational influence on earth materials. May be subaerial or subaqueous.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hillslope setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Tectonic setting in the internal part of an orogenic belt, characterized by plastic deformation of rocks accompanied by significant metamorphism, typically involving crystalline basement rocks. Typically denotes the most structurally thickened part of an orogenic belt, between a magmatic arc or collision zone and a more 'external' foreland setting.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hinterland tectonic setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting in a zone of high heat flow from the mantle. Typically identified in intraplate settings, but hot spot may also interact with active plate margins (Iceland...). Includes surface manifestations like volcanic center, but also includes crust and mantle manifestations as well.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hot spot setting

owl:Class.terms:source: Cleland, D.T., Avers, P.E., McNab, W.H., Jensen, M.E., Bailey, R.G., King, T., Russell, W.E. 1997. National Hierarchical Framework of Ecological Units, in Boyce, M. S., Haney, A., ed., Ecosystem Management Applications for Sustainable Forest and WildlifeResources: Yale University Press, New Haven, CT. pp. 181-200.
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting with seasonal climate having hot to cold or humid to arid seasons.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: humid temperate climatic setting

owl:Class.terms:source: Cleland, D.T., Avers, P.E., McNab, W.H., Jensen, M.E., Bailey, R.G., King, T., Russell, W.E. 1997. National Hierarchical Framework of Ecological Units, in Boyce, M. S., Haney, A., ed., Ecosystem Management Applications for Sustainable Forest and WildlifeResources: Yale University Press, New Haven, CT. pp. 181-200.
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting with hot humid climate influenced by equatorial air masses, no winter season.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: humid tropical climatic setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Igneous environment close to the Earth's surface, characterized by more rapid cooling than plutonic setting to produce generally fine-grained intrusive igneous rock that is commonly associated with co-magmatic volcanic rocks.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hypabyssal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting on oceanic crust formed at a spreading center that has been abandoned.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: inactive spreading center setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The ocean environment at depths between low tide level and 30 metres
owl:Class.rdfs:label: inner neritic setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A pronounced indentation of the delta front between advancing stream distributaries, occupied by shallow water, and either open to the sea or partly enclosed by minor distributaries
owl:Class.rdfs:label: interdistributary bay setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Pertaining to the benthic ocean environment or depth zone between high water and low water, also, pertaining to the organisms of that environment
owl:Class.rdfs:label: intertidal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Tectonically stable setting far from any active plate margins.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: intraplate tectonic setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The low, nearly flat, alluvial tract of land at or near the mouth of a river, commonly forming a triangular or fan-shaped plain of considerable area, crossed by many distributaries of the main river, perhaps extending beyond the general trend of the lake shore, resulting from the accumulation of sediment supplied by the river in such quantities that it is not removed by waves or currents. Most deltas are partly subaerial and partly below water.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lacustrine delta setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting associated with a lake. Always overlaps with terrestrial, may overlap with subaerial, subaqueous, or shoreline.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lacustrine setting

owl:Class.terms:source: generalize from Jackson 1997 and North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A shallow stretch of salt or brackish water, partly or completely separated from a sea or lake by an offshore reef, barrier island, sand or spit (Jackson, 1997). Water is shallow, tidal and wave-produced effects on sediments, strong light reaches sediment..
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lagoonal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Settings characterized by very low surface slope and proximity to shoreline. Generally within peritidal setting, but characterized by low surface gradients and generally low-energy sedimentary processes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: low energy shoreline setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting characterized by temperatures significantly higher that those associated with normal continental geothermal gradient.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: low pressure high temperature setting

owl:Class.terms:source: Neuendorf, K.K.E., Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p., Berggren, W.A. & Miller, K.G., 1989. Cenozoic bathyal and abyssal calcareous benthic foraminiferal zonation. Micropalaeontology 35, 308-320
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The ocean environment at depths between 1000 and 3500 metres
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lower bathyal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Continental crustal setting characterized by upper amphibolite to granulite facies metamorphism, insitu melting, residual anhydrous metamorphic rocks, and ductile flow of rock bodies.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lower continental crustal setting

owl:Class.terms:source: Readingh.G. & Collinson, J.D., 1996. Clastic coasts. 154-231 in Readingh.G. (ed.), Sedimentary Environments: Processses, Facies and Stratigraphy, third edition. Blackwell Science, Oxford
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The part of a delta plain which is penetrated by saline water and is subject to tidal processes
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lower delta plain setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: That part of the mantle that lies below a depth of about 660 km. With increasing depth, density increases from ~4.4 g/cm3-to ~5.6 g/cm3, and velocity of compressional seismic waves increases from ~10.7 km/s to ~13.7 km/s (Dziewonski and Anderson, 1981).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lower mantle setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting characterized by dominantly intrusive mafic rocks, with sheeted dike complexes in upper part and gabbroic to ultramafic intrusive or metamorphic rocks in lower part.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lower oceanic crustal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The zone of the Earth below the crust and above the core, which is divided into the upper mantle and the lower mantle, with a transition zone separating them.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: mantle setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/, based on Jackson 1997, Neuendorf et al. 2005
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting characterized by arid to semi-arid conditions on restricted coastal plains mostly above normal high tide level, with evaporite-saline mineral, tidal-flood, and eolian deposits. Boundaries with intertidal setting and non-tidal terrestrial setting are gradational. (Jackson, 1997, p. 561).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: marginal marine sabkha setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A shallow submerged plateau separated from continental landmasses, on which high biological carbonate production rates produce enough sediment to maintain the platform surface near sea level. Grades into atoll as area becomes smaller and ringing coral reefs become more prominent part of the setting.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: marine carbonate platform setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/, Webster's Encyclopedic Unabridged Dictionary of the English Language, 2001, p. 1894.
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting characterized by location under the surface of the sea.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: marine setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Produced by a mature stream swinging from side to side as it flows across its floodplain or shifts its course laterally toward the convex side of an original curve
owl:Class.rdfs:label: meandering river channel setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Spreading center at which the opening rate is between 50 and 100 mm per year.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: medium rate spreading center setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Ocean highland associated with a divergent continental margin (spreading center). Setting is characterized by active volcanism, locally steep reliefhydrothermal activity, and pelagic sedimentation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: mid ocean ridge setting

owl:Class.terms:source: Berggren, W.A. & Miller, K.G., 1989. Cenozoic bathyal and abyssal calcareous benthic foraminiferal zonation. Micropalaeontology 35, 308-320
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The ocean environment at water depths between 600 and 1000 metres
owl:Class.rdfs:label: middle bathyal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Continental crustal setting characterized by greenschist to upper amphibolite facies metamorphism, plutonic igneous rocks, and ductile deformation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: middle continental crust setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The ocean environment at depths between 30 and 100 metres
owl:Class.rdfs:label: middle neritic setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/, Jackson, 1997
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A relatively level area of fine grained material (e.g. silt) along a shore (as in a sheltered estuary or chenier-plain) or around an island, alternately covered and uncovered by the tide or covered by shallow water, and barren of vegetation. Includes most tidal flats, but lacks denotation of tidal influence..
owl:Class.rdfs:label: mud flat setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The ocean environment at depths between low-tide level and 200 metres, or between low-tide level and approximately the edge of the continental shelf
owl:Class.rdfs:label: neritic setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Broad category for subaqueous marine settings characterized by significant relief above adjacent sea floor.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ocean highland setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: That type of the Earth's crust which underlies the ocean basins. The oceanic crust is 5-10 km thick, it has a density of 2.9 g/cm3, and compressional seismic-wave velocities travelling through it at 4-7.2 km/sec. Setting in crust produced by submarine volcanism at a mid ocean ridge.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: oceanic crustal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Region of elevated ocean crust that commonly rises to within 2-3 km of the surface above an abyssal sea floor that lies several km deeper. Climate and water depths are such that a marine carbonate platform does not develop.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: oceanic plateau setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The ocean environment at depths between 100 and 200 metres or between low-tide level and approximately the edge of the continental shelf
owl:Class.rdfs:label: outer neritic setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Boundary of continental crust into oceanic crust of an oceanic basin that is not a subduction zone or transform fault system. Generally is rifted margin formed when ocean basin was initially formed.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: passive continental margin setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/, NRCS, 2001
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A gently sloping erosional surface developed at the foot of a receding hill or mountain slope. The surface may be essentially bare, exposing earth material that extends beneath adjacent uplands, or it may be thinly mantled with alluvium and colluvium, ultimately in transit from upland front to basin or valley lowland. In hill-foot slope terrain the mantle is designated \pedisediment.\ The term has been used in several geomorphic contexts: Pediments may be classed with respect to (a) landscape positions, for example, intermontane-basin piedmont or valley-border footslope surfaces (respectively, apron and terrace pediments (Cooke and Warren, 1973)), (b) type of material eroded, bedrock or regolith, or (c) combinations of the above. Compare - Piedmont slope..
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pediment setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Location on gentle slope at the foot of a mountain, generally used in terms of intermontane-basin terrain. Main components include: (a) An erosional surface on bedrock adjacent to the receding mountain front (pediment, rock pediment), (b) A constructional surface comprising individual alluvial fans and interfan valleys, also near the mountain front, and (c) A distal complex of coalescent fans (bajada), and alluvial slopes without fan form. Piedmont slopes grade to basin-floor depressions with alluvial and temporary lake plains or to surfaces associated with through drainage.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: piedmont slope system setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Geologic environments within the solid Earth.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: earth interior setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Geologic environments on all or part of the surface of the solid Earth. Based on an assumption that a particular setting may be specified by a combination of climatic, process or geomorpologic settings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: earth surface setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Tectonic setting at the boundary between two tectonic plates.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: plate margin setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Tectonic setting where new oceanic crust is being or has been formed at a divergent plate boundary. Includes active and inactive spreading centers.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: plate spreading center setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The usually dry and nearly level plain that occupies the lowest parts of closed depressions, such as those occurring on intermontane basin floors. Temporary flooding occurs primarily in response to precipitation-runoff events.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: playa setting

owl:Class.terms:source: Cleland, D.T., Avers, P.E., McNab, W.H., Jensen, M.E., Bailey, R.G., King, T., Russell, W.E. 1997. National Hierarchical Framework of Ecological Units, in Boyce, M. S., Haney, A., ed., Ecosystem Management Applications for Sustainable Forest and WildlifeResources: Yale University Press, New Haven, CT. pp. 181-200.
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting with climate dominated by temperatures below the freezing temperature of water. Includes polar deserts because precipitation is generally scant at high latitude. Climate controlled by arctic air masses, cold dry environment with short summer.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polar climatic setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The part of a delta that is below the effective depth of wave erosion, lying beyond the delta front, and sloping gently down to the floor of the basin into which the delta is advancing and where clastic river sediment ceases to be a significant part of the basin-floor deposits, it is entirely below the water level
owl:Class.rdfs:label: prodelta setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Immediately in front of or just beyond the outer limits of a glacier or ice sheet, generally at or near its lower end, said of lakes, streams, deposits, and other features produced by or derived from the glacier ice
owl:Class.rdfs:label: proglacial setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A stony platform of reef rock, landward of the reef crest at or above the low tide level, occasionally with patches of living coral and associated organisms, and commonly strewn with coral fragments and coral sand. It may include shallow pools, irregular gullies, low islands of sand or rubble (often vegetated, esp. by palms), and scattered colonies of the more hardy species of coral
owl:Class.rdfs:label: reef flat setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Metamorphism not obviously localized along contacts of igneous bodies, includes burial metamorphism and ocean ridge metamorphism
owl:Class.rdfs:label: regional metamorphic setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The bed where a natural body of surface water flows or may flow, a natural passageway or depression of perceptible extent containing continuously or periodically flowing water, or forming a connecting link between two bodies of water, a watercourse
owl:Class.rdfs:label: river channel setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Geologic setting dominated by a river system, river plains may occur in any climatic setting. Includes active channels, abandoned channels, levees, oxbow lakes, flood plain. May be part of an alluvial plain that includes terraces composed of abandoned river plain deposits.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: river plain system setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Shoreline with significant relief and abundant rock outcrop.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: rocky coast setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A sand-covered plain dominated by aeolian processes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sand plain setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting that consists of a conical mountain on the ocean floor (guyot). Typically characterized by active volcanism, pelagic sedimentation. If the mountain is high enough to reach the photic zone, carbonate production may result in reef building to produce a carbonate platform or atoll setting.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: seamount setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Geologic settings characterized by location adjacent to the ocean or a lake. A zone of indefinite width (may be many kilometers), bordering a body of water that extends from the water line inland to the first major change in landform features. Includes settings that may be subaerial, intermittently subaqueous, or shallow subaqueous, but are intrinsically associated with the interface between land areas and water bodies.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: shoreline settings

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The part of a subaqueous basin that is between a bordering shelf setting, which separate the basin from an adjacent landmass, and a very low-relief basin plain setting.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: slope rise setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Spreading center at which the opening rate is less than 50 mm per year.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: slow spreading center setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A prograded shore built seaward by waves and currents, and continuous for some distance along the coast. It is characterized by subparallel beach ridges and swales, in places with associated dunes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: strandplain setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting at the interface between the solid earth and the atmosphere, includes some shallow subaqueous settings in river channels and playas. Characterized by conditions and processes, such as erosion, that exist or operate in the open air on or immediately adjacent to the land surface
owl:Class.rdfs:label: subaerial setting

owl:Class.terms:source: based on North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/,
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting situated in or under permanent, standing water. Used for marine and lacustrine settings, but not for fluvial settings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: subaqueous setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Tectonic setting at which a tectonic plate, usually oceanic, is moving down into the mantle beneath another overriding plate.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: subduction zone setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Formed or accumulated in or by the bottom parts of a glacier or ice sheet, said of meltwater streams, till, moraine, etc.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: subglacial setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Large fan-shaped cones of sediment on the ocean floor, generally associated with submarine canyons that provide sediment supply to build the fan..
owl:Class.rdfs:label: submarine fan setting

owl:Class.terms:source: North American Geologic-map Data Model Science Language Technical Team, 2004, Sedimentary materials:science language for their classification, description, and interpretation in digital geologic-map databases, Version 1.0 (12/18/2004): U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2004-1451 appendix C, 595 p., accessed at http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2004/1451/sltt/appendixC/
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Carried upon, deposited from, or pertaining to the top surface of a glacier or ice sheet, said of meltwater streams, till, drift, etc. (Jackson, 1997, p. 639). Dreimanis (1988, p. 39) recommendation that \supraglacial\ supersede \superglacial\ is followed.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: supraglacial setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Pertaining to the shore area marginal to the littoral zone, just above high-tide level
owl:Class.rdfs:label: supratidal setting

owl:Class.terms:source: Neuendorf et al 2005, Soil Science Society of America, 1997.
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A water-saturated, periodically wet or continually flooded area with the surface not deeply submerged, essentially without the formation of peat. Marshes are characterized by sedges, cattails, rushes, or other aquatic and grasslike vegetation. Swamps are characterized by tree and brush vegetation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: swamp or marsh setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting defined by relationships to tectonic plates on or in the Earth.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tectonically defined setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting characterized by absence of direct marine influence. Most of the subaerial settings are also terrestrial, but lacustrine settings, while terrestrial, are not subaerial, so the subaerial settings are not included as subcategories.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: terrestrial setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A major channel followed by the tidal currents, extending from offshore into a tidal marsh or a tidal flat.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tidal channel setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An extensive, nearly horizontal, barren tract of land that is alternately covered and uncovered by the tide, and consisting of unconsolidated sediment (mostly mud and sand). It may form the top surface of a deltaic deposit.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tidal flat setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A marsh bordering a coast (as in a shallow lagoon or sheltered bay), formed of mud and of the resistant mat of roots of salt-tolerant plants, and regularly inundated during high tides, a marshy tidal flat.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tidal marsh setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting subject to tidal processes
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tidal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Plate boundary at which the adjacent plates are moving laterally relative to each other.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: transform plate boundary setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Crust formed in the transition zone between continental and oceanic crust, during the history of continental rifting that culminates in the formation of a new ocean.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: transitional crustal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting characterized by pressures characteristic of upper mantle, but indicated by mineral assemblage in crustal composition rocks.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ultra high pressure crustal setting

owl:Class.terms:source: Berggren, W.A. & Miller, K.G., 1989. Cenozoic bathyal and abyssal calcareous benthic foraminiferal zonation. Micropalaeontology 35, 308-320
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The ocean environment at water depths between 200 and 600 metres
owl:Class.rdfs:label: upper bathyal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Continental crustal setting dominated by non metamorphosed to low greenschist facies metamorphic rocks, and brittle deformation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: upper continental crustal setting

owl:Class.terms:source: Readingh.G. & Collinson, J.D., 1996. Clastic coasts. 154-231 in Readingh.G. (ed.), Sedimentary Environments: Processses, Facies and Stratigraphy, third edition. Blackwell Science, Oxford
owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The part of a delta plain essentially unaffected by basinal processes. They do not differ substantially from alluvial environments except that areas of swamp, marsh and lakes are usually more widespread and channels may bifurcate downstream
owl:Class.rdfs:label: upper delta plain setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: That part of the mantle which lies above a depth of about 660 km and has a density of 3.4 g/cm3 to 4.0 g/cm3 with increasing depth. Similarly, P-wave velocity increases from about 8 to 11 km/sec with depth and S wave velocity increases from about 4.5 to 6 km/sec with depth. It is presumed to be peridotitic in composition. It includes the subcrustal lithosphere the asthenosphere and the transition zone,
owl:Class.rdfs:label: upper mantle setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oceanic crustal setting dominated by extrusive rocks, abyssal oceanic sediment, with increasing mafic intrusive rock in lower part.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: upper oceanic crustal setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A generally curvillinear belt of volcanoes above a subduction zone.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: volcanic arc setting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Setting characterized by gentle surface slope, and at least intermittent presence of standing water, which may be fresh, brackish, or saline. Wetland may be terrestrial setting or shoreline setting.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: wetland setting
